sentence: when we disaggregate the economy-wide labor market statistics, we often find significant and persistent racial disparities.4 for many decades, the unemployment rate of african americans has been nearly double the national unemployment rate, with little indication that the relative difference is narrowing or that it can be fully accounted for by education or sectoral mix; the unemployment rate for hispanics also has consistently been higher than the national unemployment rate.5 similarly, during the great recession, the unemployment rates of african americans and hispanics rose more sharply and rapidly than for workers as a whole.6 even though the unemployment rates of these groups are back around their pre-recession levels, they remain higher than the national average.

sentence: over time, the "american dream" that each generation can expect to be better off than their parents' generation has gone from being widespread to increasingly out of reach for much of the population.20 researchers have found that the reduction in economic mobility has been driven primarily by a more unequal distribution of economic growth, with slower overall gross domestic product (gdp) growth a secondary factor.21 many households had been contending with volatile incomes even before the large negative shocks of the great recession and the increase in contingent work arrangements (and the "gig" economy).22 23 unpredictable income and dangerously low emergency savings raise the strain on households and, over time, have pushed them to rely on other means, such as borrowing and government transfers, to try to meet their spending needs.24 education and homeownership have long been key paths to opportunity, but the great recession has raised some important questions about asset building strategies.
